The much-anticipated Karwa Chauth moon often graces the sky later in the evening. This isn't mere chance but stems from the moon's orbital dance, its celestial position, and Earth's geographic perspective.
Karwa Chauth occurs on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the Krishna Paksha, the moon's waning phase. Just four days after the full moon, it rises later in the evening.
The moon appears about 50 minutes later daily, so by the fourth waning night, its rise time shifts well beyond that of the full moon.
Your exact latitude and longitude dictate when the moon rises, causing moonrise times to vary between locations.
